page.title: 19CHANDER HILL HOUSE
page.content: Chander Hill is a typical Derbyshire country residence. It is based on an 18th Century farm house. The house is built in random stone with stone framed and mullioned windows, stone slate roof and coped gables. The house was modernized in 1931. There has been a farm on this site since 1208 when Serlo the Saxon Lord of Beeley Manor gave 60 acres to the monks of Beauchief Abbey. A chantry was built in approximately 1400, one stone of which can still be seen today. About 1536 Chander Hill was transferred to the Guild of the Holy Cross, Chesterfield, possibly to avoid confiscation by Henry VIII. The date of the original parts of the current house is 1731. Chander Hill is one of several old buildings in the area. Others include Hipper Hall and Somersall Hall.
